subject: RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy
msgSnippet: ... I agree as long as A is not a subclass of B. If A and B are simply two different objects then I tend to test them in independent environments. If A simply
messageBody:
> >> Your underlying hypothesis appears to be this:
> >>
> >> If class A depends on B, then there exist tests T(A) that
> test A and
> >> tests T(B) that test B such that T(A) depends on T(B).
> >
> > Actaully, no (although it isn't something I object to for
> many use cases).
> >
> > I am merely asking that I can assert that T(A) depends on T(B) [for
> > whatever reason] and I do so in T(A) [somehow] not in some separate
> suite(A).
>
> This seems to me to be the crucial point. IF you don't have
> side effects and
> IF you have decoupled code then I cannot see where
> dependencies between T(A)
> and T(B) make sense. A usually does not depend directly on B but on an
> abstract interface - B just being an implementation of that interface.

I agree as long as A is not a subclass of B. If A and B are simply two different objects then I tend to test them in independent environments. If A simply needs to create object B because it gets information from that object there are other ways to do this - plus that starts a slippery slope of munging unit tests with integration tests.
However, if A is a subclass of B then I would like a quick way to say that if B fails then don't run those tests in A that require a working B, but still run other tests against A that don't make direct calls to B. It would simply make the error tracing a bit easier and avoid running tests that I know are going to fail.
